qas.question: What stopped the planned siege at St. Malo?
How did the fleet respond to the bad weather?

answers.text: the ships sailed for the safer anchorage of St. Cast

qas.question: How did the army get to the new anchorage location?
What happened to the British army?

answers.text: a French force of 10,000 from Brest to catch up with him and open fire on the reembarkation troops

qas.question: How did the British army escape

answers.text: A rear-guard of 1,400 under General Dury held off the French while the rest of the army embarked

context: The troops were reembarked and moved to the Bay of St. Lunaire in Brittany where, on 3 September, they were landed to operate against St. Malo; however, this action proved impractical. <a0_0>Worsening weather<a0_0/> forced the two armies to separate: <a1_0>the ships sailed for the safer anchorage of St. Cast<a1_0/>, while <a2_0>the army proceeded overland.<a2_0/> The tardiness of Bligh in moving his forces allowed <a3_0>a French force of 10,000 from Brest to catch up with him and open fire on the reembarkation troops<a3_0/>. <a4_0>A rear-guard of 1,400 under General Dury held off the French while the rest of the army embarked<a4_0/>. They could not be saved; 750, including Dury, were killed and the rest captured.
